title: Wisdom and Speech
shortSummary: Proverbs 18 offers profound insights into the power of words, the value of wisdom, and the consequences of folly. It contrasts the behavior of the wise and the foolish, emphasizing the importance of humility, prudent speech, and righteous living for safety and honor.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Traditional period of Solomon's Proverbs composition

keyCharacters.name: The Fool
keyCharacters.description: A person characterized by a lack of understanding and self-control, whose speech and actions lead to personal ruin and conflict.

keyCharacters.name: The Righteous
keyCharacters.description: Those who live according to God's wisdom, finding safety and honor through humility and reliance on the LORD.

keyCharacters.name: The Talebearer
keyCharacters.description: An individual who spreads gossip and slander, causing wounds and division among people.

definitions.definition: One who spreads rumors or gossip, often causing harm to others’ reputations and relationships.
A feeling of disdain or scorn often directed toward the wicked or those who act unrighteously.
A metaphor for a place of safety and protection, symbolizing God’s name as a refuge for the righteous.
Having an arrogant or prideful attitude, often preceding downfall or destruction.

outline.heading: The Foolish and the Wise in Speech and Conduct
outline.description: This section contrasts the fool’s destructive speech and behavior with the depth and value of wisdom, highlighting how foolish words lead to conflict and ruin.

outline.heading: Protection and Pride: Safety in God and the Danger of Arrogance
outline.description: The chapter emphasizes the LORD’s name as a strong tower for the righteous, warns against slothfulness and pride, and teaches humility as the path to honor.

outline.heading: The Importance of Listening and Seeking Knowledge
outline.description: These verses instruct against premature judgment and stress the value of prudence, knowledge, and fair investigation in resolving disputes.

outline.heading: Conflict Resolution and the Power of Words
outline.description: The text discusses how disputes can be settled by chance, the difficulty of restoring a broken relationship, and the life-or-death power of the tongue.

outline.heading: Friendship, Wealth, and Favor
outline.description: The chapter concludes by affirming the blessing of a good wife, contrasting the poor and the rich in speech, and highlighting the necessity of friendliness for true friendship.

application: Guard your speech carefully, recognizing that words have the power to build up or destroy relationships and even influence life and death.
Seek humility and wisdom by listening fully before responding, avoiding rash judgments that bring shame.
Trust in the LORD as your refuge and strong tower in times of trouble rather than relying on wealth or pride.
Cultivate genuine friendships by showing kindness and faithfulness, reflecting Christ’s love in your relationships.

keyVerses.text: The name of the LORD is a strong tower: the righteous runneth into it, and is safe.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully illustrates God’s protection for those who trust in Him, encouraging believers to seek refuge in the LORD.

keyVerses.text: Death and life are in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the immense responsibility believers have in their speech, as words can bring either blessing or destruction.

keyVerses.text: He that answereth a matter before he heareth it, it is folly and shame unto him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the importance of listening fully before responding, a key principle for wise and godly communication.

keyVerses.text: Whoso findeth a wife findeth a good thing, and obtaineth favour of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms the blessing and favor from God that comes through a godly marriage relationship.
